A Letter To The Creditors
A quick look at something like the
Applied Physics Laboratory will reaffirm in
anyone's mind JHU's ties to industry and
the military. But while one knows what to
expect from the APL, it's a little distressing
to find other, supposedly more "impartial"
and "academic" branches of the University
paying their dues to special interests.
This week the House of Delegates of
the Maryland State Legislature passed a bill
that would raise the ceiling on interest rates
to 24 percent throughout the entire state
lending industry. The bill, which is the
final compromise version of a series of
previous bills, is a direct concession to
banks in Maryland, a number of which have
already shifted their credit operations to
other states where they can charge higher
interest rates. The current interest rate
ceiling in Maryland is between 12 and 18
percent, depending on the type of loan.
The bill is still in committee in the
Senate, but if, as expected, it passes, a good
share of the credit (pardon the expression)
belongs to none other than the Johns
Hopkins University Metro Center. A study
conducted by Metro Center staff economists, at the request of Governor Harry
Hughes, led the Center to recommend the
complete lifting of all interest rate ceilings
in the state.
Some might question terming the
Center's study a payment of its dues to the
banking industry; after all, the study was
conducted by academics who were supposedly interested in finding out what is
best for the people of Maryland. In isolation, this view sounds good, but two other
factors undermine it severely:
the
"stacked" membership of the Metro
Center's recommendation committee, and
the Center's history of biased studies.
The Metro-Center's Task Force on
Interest Deregulation, the group which
made the recommendations based on the
study, was made up almost entirely of
officers of major banking concerns. Committee member Margie Muller, vicepresident of Union Trust Bank and the wife
of JHU president Steven Muller, is quoted
on the front page of this issue as saying
that "it's perfectly normal" for people to
question the membership of the committee. What she doesn't seem to realize is

that the membership of the committee
invalidates both the Metro Center's claim
to acting as an academic institution and its
authority as a source of recommendation.
It may be that the actual study showed
that the banks, if not placated, would shift
their operations and thus adversely effect
customers — but it was the members of the

and Pepto-Bismol to a local medical dispensary.

Kinbirila crossing. Looking at the Manhattan
skyline, Kong, Victor, and even raw tomatoes
seemed far away.

passed within a few days. I was soon able to flush
a toilet, and the taste of chocolate ice cream soda

rare tropical disease...But no, I think it was something else. My summer in Africa had allowed me

Swimmers Vie For Titles
BY JAY SCHNEIDER
The Johns Hopkins Swimming and diving teams sent
representatives to the Division
III National Finals March 18-20
at Washington and Lee in
Lexington, Virginia. Both the
men and the women fared very
well, the women finishing sixteenth of 42, the men coming in
fifth of 75. The top six men's
teams were: Kenyon, repeating
as champion; Williams, St.
Lawrence,
Claremont-Mudd,
Hopkins, and Tufts. It was
Hopkins' lowest finishever in
this meet.
The men's meet was extremely wide open, and is
expected to get more unpredictable. Kenyon and Williams
didn't win a single individual
event; St. Lawrence won only
one. Claremont-Mudd's finish
was attributed to one swimmer
taking three individual events.
Outstanding performers for JHU
were Bill Bender, who was
second in the 400-meter individual medley, Mike Leonhardt,
who finished second in the
200-meter freestyle; and Harvey
Allen, who placed second in the
200-meter breaststroke. During
trials, Leonhardt set Blue Jay
records in the 200-meter freestyle and 100-meter freestyle
events. Hopkins' only failing, if
one must be sought, was that the
400-meter medley relay team

did not qualify for the finals.
Only one other man in the MAC
(from Franklin and Marshall)
scored in the meet. The meet's
unpredictable character was epitomized by the fact that only
one 1981 winner, in the onemeter diving event, repeated in
1982.
The women competed in
the first NCAA women's Division III National Finals. The top
five
teams were Williams,
Kenyon, Pomona-Ritzer (part of
the same college system as
Claremont-Mudd); Smith; and
Gettysburg, the MAC champion.
The MAC was very strong, with
Western Maryland and Franklin
and Marshall finishing in the top
12, and Hopkins in the sixteenth
spot. The Blue Jays swam well,
especially Heather Dick. All of
her times were a season beat,
and all of the times, except the
1650-meter freestyle, were her
lifetime best. This being the
first year of this championship,
the meet is expected to grow,
and coach Tim Welsh hopes that
JHU's contingient at the meet
will increase with it.
Welsh is looking forward to
a strong recruiting year. An excellent crop of freshmen,
coupled with the fact that
no women and only two men
will graduate from the national teams, could produce an even
more competitive and exciting
team than this year's squad.

A quick look at something like the
Applied Physics Laboratory will reaffirm in
anyone's mind JHU's ties to industry and
the military. But while one knows what to
expect from the APL, it's a little distressing
to find other, supposedly more "impartial"
and "academic" branches of the University
paying their dues to special interests.
This week the House of Delegates of
the Maryland State Legislature passed a bill
that would raise the ceiling on interest rates
to 24 percent throughout the entire state
lending industry. The bill, which is the
final compromise version of a series of
previous bills, is a direct concession to
banks in Maryland, a number of which have
already shifted their credit operations to
other states where they can charge higher
interest rates. The current interest rate
ceiling in Maryland is between 12 and 18
percent, depending on the type of loan.
The bill is still in committee in the
Senate, but if, as expected, it passes, a good
share of the credit (pardon the expression)
belongs to none other than the Johns
Hopkins University Metro Center. A study
conducted by Metro Center staff economists, at the request of Governor Harry
Hughes, led the Center to recommend the
complete lifting of all interest rate ceilings
in the state.
Some might question terming the
Center's study a payment of its dues to the
banking industry; after all, the study was
conducted by academics who were supposedly interested in finding out what is
best for the people of Maryland. In isolation, this view sounds good, but two other
factors undermine it severely:
the
"stacked" membership of the Metro

Man, we spent our last day on the road to Abidjan. We arrived in the capital of the Ivory Coast,
and we went to see Victor Diabete, who had been
anxiously awaiting our return. After hours of
telling Victor all about our Upper Voltan and
Malian adventures, we began to pack our bags for
the next day's flight. In order to save on excess
weight, we gave our bottles of aspirin, Cloroquine
and Pepto-Bismol to a local medical dispensary.
As night fell, the runway lights went on.
Our flight was announced, and we were off to
New York. After having stopped in Monrovia
(Liberia) and Dakar (Senegal), we reached cruising altitude. Dinner, which consisted of raw
tomatoes, rice, and chicken, was served some—
where over the mid-Atlantic. After our group had
exchanged final thoughts on our African experience, we each went our own way from Kennedy
International. As my taxi bounced across the
Queensborough Bridge, I remembered the excitement we had had only a few days ago at the
Kinbirila crossing. Looking at the Manhattan
skyline, Kong, Victor, and even raw tomatoes
seemed far away.
My initial culture shock to New York living
passed within a few days. I was soon able to flush
a toilet, and the taste of chocolate ice cream soda
became familiar once again. But somehow it all
seemed less important to me than it had before
my trip to Kong. Perhaps I had bought the wrong
brand of ice cream, perhaps I had contracted a
rare tropical disease...But no, I think it was something else. My summer in Africa had allowed me

life. It was a life which, so far, has been relatively

Swimmers Vie For Titles
BY JAY SCHNEIDER
The Johns Hopkins Swimming and diving teams sent
representatives to the Division
III National Finals March 18-20
at Washington and Lee in
Lexington, Virginia. Both the
men and the women fared very
well, the women finishing sixteenth of 42, the men coming in
fifth of 75. The top six men's
teams were: Kenyon, repeating
as champion; Williams, St.
Lawrence,
Claremont-Mudd,
Hopkins, and Tufts. It was
Hopkins' lowest finishever in
this meet.
The men's meet was extremely wide open, and is
expected to get more unpredictable. Kenyon and Williams
didn't win a single individual
event; St. Lawrence won only
one. Claremont-Mudd's finish
was attributed to one swimmer
taking three individual events.
Outstanding performers for JHU
were Bill Bender, who was
second in the 400-meter individual medley, Mike Leonhardt,
who finished second in the
200-meter freestyle; and Harvey
Allen, who placed second in the
200-meter breaststroke. During
trials, Leonhardt set Blue Jay
records in the 200-meter freestyle and 100-meter freestyle
events. Hopkins' only failing, if
one must be sought, was that the
400-meter medley relay team

did not qualify for the finals.
Only one other man in the MAC
(from Franklin and Marshall)
scored in the meet. The meet's
unpredictable character was epitomized by the fact that only
one 1981 winner, in the onemeter diving event, repeated in
1982.
The women competed in
the first NCAA women's Division III National Finals. The top
five
teams were Williams,
Kenyon, Pomona-Ritzer (part of
the same college system as
Claremont-Mudd); Smith; and
Gettysburg, the MAC champion.
The MAC was very strong, with
Western Maryland and Franklin
and Marshall finishing in the top
12, and Hopkins in the sixteenth
spot. The Blue Jays swam well,
especially Heather Dick. All of
her times were a season beat,
and all of the times, except the
1650-meter freestyle, were her
lifetime best. This being the
first year of this championship,
the meet is expected to grow,
and coach Tim Welsh hopes that
JHU's contingient at the meet
will increase with it.
Welsh is looking forward to
a strong recruiting year. An excellent crop of freshmen,
coupled with the fact that
no women and only two men
will graduate from the national teams, could produce an even
more competitive and exciting
team than this year's squad.
